title: 110_hr6116
content: The "Saving Family Homes Act of 2008" allows individuals the right to rent their home subject to foreclosure. The "Saving Family Homes Act of 2008" grants eligible mortgagors the option to continue occupying foreclosed property for up to 20 years if notice is provided before foreclosure proceedings begin. The "Saving Family Homes Act of 2008" allows eligible mortgagors to stay in foreclosed property for up to 20 years if they receive written notice from the foreclosing creditor stating the default, the right to continue occupancy, and the earliest date foreclosure may begin. Occupancy of foreclosed property by eligible mortgagor under periodic tenancy. Owner can terminate for breach but not at will. Mortgagor must pay fair market rent and use property as principal residence. SEC. 3. REQUIRED NOTICE. Notice for eligible mortgage must be in writing, submitted to the court and foreclosing creditor, stating the mortgagor's intent to continue occupying the foreclosed property. SEC. 4. DETERMINATION OF FAIR MARKET RENT. The fair market rent for a foreclosed property in a covered foreclosure proceeding is determined by an independent appraiser appointed by the court. It is adjusted annually based on changes in the Consumer Price Index. If the owner of a foreclosed property or eligible mortgagor requests a redetermination of fair market rent, they must agree to pay for the costs involved. The court will conduct the redetermination in the same manner as before, but no request can be made within 12 months of the previous redetermination. SEC. 5. In nonjudicial foreclosure proceedings, eligible mortgagors can seek a determination of fair market rent by filing a notice with the court. SEC. 6. This Act does not affect a creditor's right to foreclose on a mortgage. SEC. 7. Owners have the right to reinstate possession of the property. SEC. 7. RIGHT TO REINSTATEMENT. Eligible mortgagors have the right to reinstate an eligible mortgage under contract or State law. SEC. 8. JURISDICTION OF FEDERAL COURTS. Proceedings under sections 4 or 5 can be moved to the appropriate U.S. district court. SEC. 9. EFFECT ON STATE LAW. This Act does not exempt individuals from complying with State foreclosure laws unless they conflict with this Act. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. For the purposes of this Act, definitions include "covered foreclosure proceeding" for eligible mortgages, "eligible mortgagor" as the borrower, and "eligible mortgage" as a first mortgage on a single-family property used as the borrower's primary residence for at least 2 years. The covered foreclosure proceeding must involve a mortgage made before July 1, 2007, in connection with the purchase of the property for a price lower than the median purchase price in the same metropolitan statistical area or state. Residences in metropolitan areas or States are determined using data from the National Association of Realtors. Foreclosed property refers to a single-family property being foreclosed. The foreclosing creditor is the creditor foreclosing the mortgage. The owner of a foreclosed property is the person with title to the property. The term "single family property" refers to a structure with 1 to 4 dwelling units, a unit in a multi-unit condominium with an interest in common areas, or a unit in a project where purchase entitles permanent occupancy. SEC. 11. APPLICABILITY AND SUNSET. This Act applies to covered foreclosure proceedings not yet finalized at the enactment date but does not apply to proceedings initiated after 5 years from the enactment date.
